sentence.text: MicroRNA-9 (miR-9) dysregulation is implicated in a variety of human malignancies including hepatocellular carcinoma (phosphatidylinositol phosphorylation), but its role remains contradictory.
In this study, we explored the expression and methylation status of miR-9 in phosphatidylinositol phosphorylation samples, as well as the tumor-related functions of miR-9 in vitro.
Mechanically, miR-9 plays a tumor suppressive role partially through a functional miR-9/negative regulation of translation/AKTAAAAAERK axis.

Our study suggests that miR-9 functions as a tumor suppressor in phosphatidylinositol phosphorylation progression by inhibiting a series of target genes, including the newly validated miR-9/negative regulation of translation/AKTAAAAAERK axis, thus providing potential therapeutic targets and novel prognostic biomarkers for HCC patients.
